isis.stitle: TSI 91-05-03 - On Vehicle TAS Power Steering Gear Input Shaft Seal Replacement

subjectgroup.subject: On Vehicle TAS Power Steering Gear Input Shaft Seal Replacement

geninfo.para: If you have determined that an external power steering gear leak is caused by the gear input shaft seal, use this improved procedure to replace the input shaft seal on the vehicle.

svcproc.stitle: TSI 91-05-03 - On Vehicle TAS Power Steering Gear Input Shaft Seal Replacement
svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE

step1.para: Disconnect and plug the return line from the steering gear. Also cap the return port of the steering gear with a high pressure fitting ( Figure 1).
Remove the steering column from the gear input shaft ( Figure 2).
Remove the dirt and water seal from the steering gear ( Figure 3).

figure.caption: Figure 3. Remove Dirt And Water Seal

step1.para: Wipe out the grease and remove the spiral retaining ring. Use a screwdriver inserted into the notch formed in the end of the ring ( Figure 4).
Slip the steering column back onto the input shaft with the pinch bolt installed, but not tightened ( Figure 5).
Tie or wrap a shop towel around the input shaft ( Figure 6) and place a drip pan under the vehicle to catch oil.
Add fluid as necessary to fill the power steering reservoir to the fill line on the dip stick ( Figure 7).

note.para: Do not mix oil types. Refer to GROUP 10, LUBRICATION in the Service Manual for the proper type of oil to use.

step1.para: With the vehicle in neutral, the wheels blocked to prevent vehicle movement, momentarily turn the starter (quickly turn off the engine if it starts).
Remove the shop towel from around the input shaft. Disconnect the steering column and remove the input shaft seal ( Figure 8).
Check the seal area of the valve housing for seal fragments. Remove any that are found ( Figure 9).

Check the removed input shaft seal for heat damage. If the seal is stiff and brittle, and not pliable it is probably heat damaged ( Figure 10). Determine and fix the cause of excessive heat in the system.

Put clean grease on the new input shaft seal and place over the input shaft, garter spring side toward the gear. Use a seal installer tool to install the seal. Put the seal installer over the input shaft and against the seal. Tap the seal installer until the tool shoulder is square against the valve housing. Remove any seal material that may have sheared off in the seal bore retaining ring groove ( Figure 11).
Insert new retaining ring into the retaining ring groove ( Figure 12).

Pack the end of the valve housing bore around the input shaft with clean high temperature industrial grease. Apply more grease to a new dirt and water seal and install it over the input shaft seal. Seat it in the groove behind the shaft serrations and against the valve housing ( Figure 13).

figure.caption: Figure 13. Install The Dirt And Water Seal

step1.para: Install the steering column onto the input shaft ( Figure 14) and tighten to 70 to 75 lb. ft. (95 to 102 Nm). A 7/16-20 prevailing torque fastener assembly is required. If original fastener is lost or damaged, replace with Navistar service part number 586263C1 Bolt, 273896 Bolt.
Reconnect the return line to the steering gear return port ( Figure 15).

Fill the reservoir nearly full. Start and run the engine for 10 seconds. Shut the engine off and check and refill the power steering reservoir. Repeat this operation at least three times, each time check and refill the power steering reservoir.
Start the engine and let idle for two minutes. Shut the engine off and check the fluid level in the power steering reservoir.
Start the engine and steer the vehicle from full left to full right turn several times. Add fluid as necessary to the full line on the power steering reservoir dip stick.
Remove air from a gear mounted in an inverted position and equipped with a manual bleed screw by first following step 17.

With the engine idling and no steering action, loosen the manual bleed screw about one turn allowing air and aerated fluid to bleed out around the bleed screw until only clear (non-aerated) fluid is observed. Close the bleed screw and check and fill the power steering reservoir.

Repeat this procedure 3 or 4 times until only clear (non-aerated) fluid is discharged when the screw is loosened. Tighten the manual bleed screw to 27 to 33 in. lbs. (3.1 to 3.7 Nm). Check and refill the power steering reservoir.

note.para: Do not steer the vehicle while the bleed screw is loose.
